title: Employees Earning More Than Managers
markdown:
# **Employees Earning More Than Managers**

**Difficulty:** Medium  •  **Tags:** `SELF JOIN`



## **Problem Description**

Find all employees who earn more than their managers.



## **Table Schema**

**employees**
```
+------------+------+
| Column     | Type |
+------------+------+
| id         | INT  |
| name       | TEXT |
| salary     | INT  |
| manager_id | INT  |
+------------+------+
```



## **Example**

### **Input**

**employees**
```
+----+-------+--------+------------+
| id | name  | salary | manager_id |
+----+-------+--------+------------+
| 1  | Joe   | 70000  | 3          |
| 2  | Henry | 80000  | 4          |
| 3  | Sam   | 60000  | None       |
| 4  | Max   | 90000  | None       |
+----+-------+--------+------------+
```

### **Expected Output**

```
+----------+
| Employee |
+----------+
| Joe      |
+----------+
```

testCases.setupSql: CREATE TABLE employees(id INT, name TEXT, salary INT, manager_id INT); INSERT INTO employees VALUES (1,'Joe',70000,3),(2,'Henry',80000,4),(3,'Sam',60000,NULL),(4,'Max',90000,NULL);
testCases.solutionSql: SELECT e.name as Employee FROM employees e JOIN employees m ON e.manager_id = m.id WHERE e.salary > m.salary;

testCases.setupSql: CREATE TABLE employees(id INT, name TEXT, salary INT, manager_id INT);
testCases.solutionSql: SELECT e.name as Employee FROM employees e JOIN employees m ON e.manager_id = m.id WHERE e.salary > m.salary;

testCases.setupSql: CREATE TABLE employees(id INT, name TEXT, salary INT, manager_id INT); INSERT INTO employees VALUES (1,'Joe',70000,3),(2,'Henry',80000,4),(3,'Sam',60000,NULL),(4,'Max',90000,NULL);
testCases.solutionSql: SELECT e.name as Employee FROM employees e JOIN employees m ON e.manager_id = m.id WHERE e.salary > m.salary;
